details: Satirical fiction exposes human folly, often in absurd or exaggerated ways, to provoke thought and reflection.

name: Science
description: Nonfiction and educational works that explore scientific discoveries, theories, and research.
notes: Includes topics such as physics, biology, chemistry, and astronomy.
details: Science literature can be academic (textbooks, research papers) or popular (books aimed at general audiences).

name: Science & Nature
description: Books focused on scientific discoveries, natural phenomena, and technological advancements.
notes: Includes topics such as astrophysics, environmental science, and medicine.
details: This genre aims to educate and engage readers with accessible or in-depth scientific knowledge.

name: Science Fantasy
description: A blend of science fiction and fantasy, where elements of both genres coexist.
notes: Often features advanced technology alongside magical or supernatural elements.
details: Examples include works like 'Star Wars' and the 'Dune' series by Frank Herbert.

name: Science Fiction
description: A speculative fiction genre exploring futuristic, scientific, or technological themes.
notes: Often involves space travel, time travel, artificial intelligence, and dystopian settings.
details: Science fiction examines the impact of scientific advancements on humanity and society, blending imaginative concepts with scientific reasoning.

name: Scientific Works
description: Publications that present scientific research, theories, and discoveries.
notes: Includes journal articles, textbooks, and research papers.
details: Scientific works contribute to academic knowledge, advancing fields such as physics, biology, and engineering.

name: Sea Story
description: A genre centered on maritime adventures, naval warfare, and life at sea.
notes: Includes both fiction and nonfiction accounts of sailors, pirates, and naval battles.
details: Sea stories often depict survival, exploration, and human resilience against the forces of nature.

name: Self-Help
description: A genre focused on personal development, motivation, and guidance.
notes: Topics include mental well-being, financial success, and productivity.
details: Self-help books aim to provide strategies for improving various aspects of life, often offering practical exercises and inspirational content.

name: Sentimental Fiction
description: A genre focused on evoking emotional responses from the reader, often centered around themes of love, loss, and moral lessons.
notes: Typically features idealized characters and situations designed to appeal to the reader’s emotions.
details: Classic examples include works by authors like Jane Austen and the works of Charles Dickens.

name: Short Stories
description: A form of fiction that tells a complete story within a short length, typically under 10,000 words.
notes: Common in literary magazines and anthologies.
details: Short stories often focus on a single moment, character, or theme with concise storytelling.

name: Short Story
description: A genre focusing on short works of fiction, typically under 20,000 words, which aim to focus on a specific theme or character.
notes: Short stories are usually more concise than novels, often leaving much to interpretation or focusing on a pivotal moment in a character's life.
details: Famous collections include 'The Complete Short Stories of Ernest Hemingway' and 'The Stories of John Cheever.'

name: Short Story Collection
description: A genre where multiple short stories by an author are collected in one volume.
notes: Short stories in a collection often explore a range of themes or a single recurring motif.
details: Famous collections include 'Dubliners' by James Joyce and 'Interpreter of Maladies' by Jhumpa Lahiri.

name: Silkpunk
description: A genre blending Asian-inspired aesthetics and ancient technology with speculative fiction.
notes: Coined by author Ken Liu to describe his own works.
details: Silkpunk features airships, organic technology, and martial arts within fantastical worlds.

name: Skepticism
description: A genre that involves questioning accepted beliefs, particularly in areas like religion, science, and philosophy, promoting doubt and critical thinking.
notes: Skeptical works often challenge traditional notions of truth, reality, or authority and encourage readers to question the status quo.
details: Notable works include 'The Demon-Haunted World' by Carl Sagan and 'The God Delusion' by Richard Dawkins.

name: Slipstream
description: A genre that blends literary fiction with speculative elements, often creating a surreal or unsettling effect.
notes: Defies traditional genre boundaries, merging realism with the fantastic.
details: Slipstream fiction challenges perceptions of reality, leaving readers with a sense of cognitive dissonance.

name: Slipstream Fiction
description: A genre that blends literary fiction with speculative elements, often creating an uncanny effect.
notes: Blurred lines between reality and the surreal.
details: Slipstream books challenge conventional narratives, presenting the familiar in strange and unpredictable ways.

name: Social Commentary
description: A genre that critiques social structures, issues, and cultural norms.
notes: Often found in essays, literature, and journalism.
details: Social commentary raises awareness of injustices, advocating for change through analysis and critique.

name: Social Criticism
description: Works that analyze, critique, and challenge social structures, norms, and issues.
notes: May be presented in essays, books, or journalistic pieces.
details: Social criticism explores topics such as inequality, cultural shifts, and political movements.

name: Social Fiction
description: A genre that addresses societal issues, inequalities, and human experiences within specific cultural or historical contexts.
notes: Social fiction often explores themes of justice, discrimination, and human rights, with a focus on character-driven narratives that reflect broader social movements.
details: Works like 'To Kill a Mockingbird' by Harper Lee and 'The Grapes of Wrath' by John Steinbeck exemplify this genre.

name: Social History
description: Explores the history of societies and the lives of common people, focusing on social structures and cultural norms.
notes: Often overlaps with sociology and anthropology.
details: Books in this genre examine how communities function, evolve, and how various groups have lived across different historical periods.

name: Social Novel
description: A novel that addresses social issues, often focusing on the struggles of individuals within a larger societal context.
notes: Can deal with themes like poverty, class struggles, and injustice.
details: Famous examples include works like Charles Dickens' 'Oliver Twist' and Upton Sinclair's 'The Jungle.'

name: Social Satire
description: Humorous and critical works that mock societal norms, politics, or culture.
notes: Satire often uses irony and exaggeration.
details: Famous examples include works like Jonathan Swift's 'Gulliver's Travels' and George Orwell's '1984.'

name: Social Science
description: The study of society and human behavior, encompassing various disciplines like sociology, economics, and anthropology.
notes: Works in this genre can be empirical, theoretical, or practical.
details: Social science books range from academic research to popular books that explain societal trends and issues.

name: Sociology
description: Books examining human society, social relationships, and cultural phenomena.
notes: Includes studies on social behavior, institutions, and group dynamics.
details: Sociology books analyze social structures, inequalities, and the impact of institutions on individual and collective behavior.

name: Soft Science Fiction
description: Science fiction that focuses on social sciences, psychology, and philosophy rather than hard technology.
notes: Less emphasis on scientific accuracy, more on speculative ideas and human experiences.
details: Soft sci-fi often explores sociology, ethics, and cultural evolution in futuristic or alternative settings.

name: Software Engineering
description: Publications focusing on the principles and practices of software development.
notes: Includes programming methodologies, system design, and best practices.
details: Software engineering literature guides developers in building, maintaining, and optimizing software systems.

name: Solarpunk
description: A speculative genre that envisions optimistic futures with sustainable technology and ecological harmony.
notes: Thematically opposed to cyberpunk, focusing on solutions to environmental and social issues.
details: Solarpunk promotes green energy, social cooperation, and futuristic societies that prioritize ecological balance.

name: Southern Gothic
description: A subgenre of Gothic fiction set in the American South, often featuring decay, grotesque characters, and social issues.
notes: Explores themes of racial tension, poverty, and moral corruption.
details: Southern Gothic literature blends horror, satire, and psychological complexity, often exposing societal flaws.

name: Space & Astronomy
description: Books exploring the universe, celestial bodies, and space exploration.
notes: Includes astrophysics, cosmology, and space missions.
details: Space and astronomy books delve into black holes, planetary science, and the future of space travel.

name: Space Exploration
description: Works that focus on the exploration of space, including the history of space missions, theoretical discussions, and speculative fiction about life beyond Earth.
notes: Can include both non-fiction and science fiction.
details: Space exploration books can include astronaut biographies, scientific research on space, and fictional works like those of Arthur C. Clarke and Isaac Asimov.

name: Space Opera
description: A subgenre of science fiction characterized by epic adventures, large-scale conflicts, and advanced spacefaring civilizations.
notes: Typically features heroic characters, intergalactic battles, and complex political intrigue.
details: Space opera blends action, drama, and imaginative world-building, often with a sweeping, grandiose narrative.

name: Speculative Fiction
description: A broad genre encompassing science fiction, fantasy, and alternative history.
notes: Imagines worlds different from reality through futuristic, supernatural, or hypothetical scenarios.
details: Speculative fiction challenges reality, exploring new possibilities and ideas.

name: Spirituality & Religion
description: A genre focusing on religious beliefs, spiritual growth, and philosophical reflections.
notes: Includes sacred texts, self-discovery books, and theological discussions.
details: Books in this genre explore spiritual traditions, practices, and personal growth through religious or philosophical lenses.

name: Splatterpunk
description: A horror subgenre that emphasizes extreme violence, gore, and graphic imagery.
notes: Known for its shocking and unfiltered portrayal of horror elements.
details: Splatterpunk stories push boundaries with disturbing content, often exploring the darkest aspects of human nature.

name: Sports
description: A genre that revolves around sports, whether through fiction, nonfiction, or biographies of athletes and teams.
notes: Sports books may cover inspirational stories, game analysis, or the cultural impact of sports.
details: Notable works include 'Friday Night Lights' by H.G. Bissinger and 'Open' by Andre Agassi.

name: Sports & Recreation
description: Books about sports history, training techniques, and athletic achievements.
notes: Includes autobiographies of athletes, guides to fitness, and analysis of sports psychology.
details: Sports books provide insights into competition, team dynamics, and physical conditioning for various activities.

name: Spy Fiction
description: A genre that involves espionage, intelligence agents, and covert operations, often set during times of political tension or warfare.
notes: Spy fiction typically features secret agents, covert missions, and high-stakes action, with a focus on intrigue and deception.
details: Famous works include 'The Spy Who Came in from the Cold' by John le Carré and 'Casino Royale' by Ian Fleming.

name: Steampunk
description: A subgenre of speculative fiction set in a world inspired by Victorian-era technology, often featuring steam-powered machinery.
notes: Blends historical settings with advanced, retro-futuristic inventions.
details: Steampunk aesthetics include gears, airships, and alternate histories where steam technology reigns supreme.

name: Steampunk & Gaslamp Fantasy
description: Books blending Victorian aesthetics with advanced technology and fantasy.
notes: Includes stories set in anachronistic, steam-powered worlds.
details: Steampunk books explore alternative technologies, airships, and retro-futuristic inventions.

name: Supernatural
description: A genre that explores phenomena beyond the natural world, including ghosts, spirits, and other supernatural entities or events.
notes: Supernatural fiction often blends horror, mystery, and fantasy, creating an atmosphere of fear or wonder in the face of unexplained occurrences.
details: Famous works include 'The Haunting of Hill House' by Shirley Jackson and 'The Shining' by Stephen King.

name: Supernatural Horror
description: Horror fiction that incorporates ghosts, demons, or other paranormal elements.
notes: Often involves hauntings, possessions, and unexplained phenomena.
details: Supernatural horror builds fear through eerie atmospheres, psychological tension, and interactions with the unknown.

name: Survival & Disaster Preparedness
description: Books providing knowledge on surviving in extreme situations and preparing for emergencies.
notes: Includes wilderness survival, urban disaster preparedness, and self-sufficiency.
details: Survival books offer guidance on food storage, shelter building, emergency first aid, and strategies for coping with natural disasters.

name: Survival Fiction
description: A genre that focuses on characters facing extreme circumstances where they must survive in hostile environments, often isolated from civilization.
notes: The genre frequently explores themes of resilience, self-sufficiency, and human ingenuity.
details: Well-known examples include 'The Martian' by Andy Weir and 'Hatchet' by Gary Paulsen.

name: Suspense
description: A genre that creates tension, excitement, and anticipation, often involving mysteries or high-stakes situations.
notes: Common in thrillers, crime fiction, and horror.
details: Suspense literature keeps readers engaged with plot twists, cliffhangers, and psychological tension.

name: Thriller
description: A fast-paced genre that builds tension, suspense, and excitement.
notes: Includes psychological thrillers, espionage thrillers, and legal thrillers.
details: Thrillers often feature high stakes, unexpected twists, and protagonists facing danger or moral dilemmas.

name: Time Travel
description: A genre of speculative fiction that explores the concept of traveling through time, whether to the past or the future.
notes: Time travel stories often deal with paradoxes, alternate realities, and the consequences of changing the past.
details: Popular examples include 'The Time Machine' by H.G. Wells and 'Doctor Who' TV series.

name: Time Travel Fiction
description: Stories that explore the effects and paradoxes of time travel.
notes: Can be science fiction-based or involve mystical elements.
details: Time travel fiction examines causality, destiny, and the philosophical implications of altering history.

name: Tragedy
description: A genre that depicts human suffering, loss, and often ends in catastrophe.
notes: Rooted in classical literature and drama.
details: Tragedies explore themes of fate, morality, and personal downfall.

name: Travel
description: A genre focused on the exploration and description of different regions, cultures, and experiences encountered during travel.
notes: Travel literature often includes both personal narratives and objective accounts, offering insights into the author's journeys and the places they visit.
details: Notable works include 'In Patagonia' by Bruce Chatwin and 'The Road to Oxiana' by Robert Byron.

name: Travel & Adventure
description: Books about exploration, cultural experiences, and travel guides.
notes: Includes memoirs of explorers, travel journalism, and city guides.
details: Travel books provide insights into different cultures, adventure sports, and unique destinations around the world.

name: Travel Literature
description: A genre that documents experiences of travel, exploration, and adventure.
notes: Includes memoirs, guidebooks, and historical accounts.
details: Travel literature captures cultural insights, landscapes, and personal reflections on journeys.

name: Travel Narrative
description: A type of literature in which the author recounts their travels and the experiences they had during their journey.
notes: Often mixed with cultural exploration and reflections on the places visited.
details: Travel narratives can include both factual descriptions and personal reflections, offering insights into the writer's experiences in foreign lands.

name: Travel Writing
description: Works that describe the experiences of an individual or group traveling to new or foreign places.
notes: Includes both personal reflection and factual descriptions of places, cultures, and customs.
details: Travel writing can range from travelogues to adventure narratives and can include elements of history, geography, and cultural critique.

name: Travelogue
description: Books or writings that describe the author's travel experiences, often including cultural, historical, and geographical details.
notes: Commonly includes personal reflections on the places visited.
details: Travelogues often explore exotic or foreign destinations, but can also include journeys of self-discovery.

name: True Crime
description: A genre that explores real-life crimes, criminal psychology, and investigative journalism.
notes: Often features detailed accounts of criminal cases and forensic analysis.
details: True crime books provide insights into real cases, exploring criminal behavior, law enforcement procedures, and justice system complexities.

name: Unfinished Novel
description: A genre consisting of works that were left incomplete by the author, often due to external circumstances like death or writer's block.
notes: These works can sometimes be finished posthumously by other writers or editors.
details: Unfinished novels may offer insight into the author's creative process and can be seen as a form of literary puzzle for readers and scholars.

name: Urban Fantasy
description: Fantasy set in a modern or urban setting, often featuring magical elements coexisting with the real world.
notes: Often includes supernatural beings, secret societies, and hidden magic.
details: Urban fantasy blends contemporary life with mythological creatures, magic, and supernatural mysteries.

name: Urban Studies
description: Books about city planning, architecture, and urban sociology.
notes: Includes studies on smart cities, urban policy, and community development.
details: Urban studies books explore the social, economic, and environmental aspects of city life.

name: Utopian Fiction
description: Books that depict idealized societies, often exploring philosophical and political ideas.
notes: Contrasts with dystopian fiction by presenting optimistic visions of the future.
details: Utopian fiction offers speculative solutions to social problems, imagining harmonious and progressive societies.

name: War
description: A genre that explores themes of conflict, particularly military and combat situations, and their impact on individuals, societies, and nations.
notes: War literature often highlights the psychological and moral challenges faced by soldiers and civilians, as well as the broader consequences of war.
details: Notable works include 'All Quiet on the Western Front' by Erich Maria Remarque and 'The Things They Carried' by Tim O'Brien.

name: War Fiction
description: A genre that focuses on war and its impact on individuals and societies.
notes: Covers historical and modern conflicts, often featuring soldiers, civilians, and political consequences.
details: Explores the brutality of war, psychological trauma, heroism, and moral dilemmas faced in combat.

name: War Novel
description: A genre that focuses on the experience of war, typically exploring the emotional and psychological effects of combat on soldiers and civilians.
notes: War novels often address themes of heroism, trauma, and the moral implications of violence and conflict.
details: Examples include 'All Quiet on the Western Front' by Erich Maria Remarque and 'A Farewell to Arms' by Ernest Hemingway.

name: Weird Fiction
description: A genre that blends horror, fantasy, and science fiction with surreal and unexplainable elements.
notes: Popularized by writers like H.P. Lovecraft, focusing on cosmic horror and the unknown.
details: Weird fiction often challenges reality, featuring otherworldly entities, psychological terror, and existential dread.

name: Western
description: Books set in the American frontier, featuring cowboys, outlaws, and lawmen.
notes: Includes classic Western novels, historical accounts, and revisionist Westerns.
details: Western books capture the rugged individualism, conflicts, and landscapes of the Old West.

name: Wildlife
description: Books that focus on animals, ecosystems, and conservation efforts.
notes: Includes nature writing, field guides, and ecological studies.
details: Wildlife literature educates readers about biodiversity, endangered species, and human impact on nature.

name: Wine & Spirits
description: Books about wine-making, brewing, and mixology.
notes: Includes guides to wine tasting, whiskey history, and cocktail recipes.
details: These books cover the science of fermentation, vineyard management, and the art of pairing drinks with food.

name: Witchcraft & Paganism
description: Books exploring Wicca, pagan rituals, and magical practices.
notes: Includes historical texts, modern spell books, and religious studies.
details: These books discuss the history of witchcraft, spiritual traditions, and practices such as herbal magic and divination.

name: Writing
description: Books about the craft of writing, including guidance on style, technique, and the business of writing.
notes: Includes instructional materials for aspiring writers and reflections by authors on their own writing processes.
details: Notable examples include 'On Writing' by Stephen King and 'Bird by Bird' by Anne Lamott.

name: Young Adult
description: Books specifically written for young readers, typically between the ages of 12 and 18.
notes: Deals with themes of personal growth, relationships, and challenges faced by adolescents.
details: Genres within young adult literature include fantasy, romance, and realistic fiction, with notable examples like 'The Hunger Games' and 'Harry Potter.'

name: Young Adult (YA)
description: A genre targeting teenage audiences, typically featuring coming-of-age themes.
notes: Includes dystopian, fantasy, contemporary, and romance subgenres.
details: YA fiction often explores themes of identity, self-discovery, and social issues while maintaining an engaging, accessible narrative style.

name: Young Adult Fiction
description: A genre targeting a teenage audience, often dealing with themes of growing up, self-discovery, and coming-of-age.
notes: Although initially aimed at adolescents, many young adult novels are enjoyed by adults as well.
details: Popular works in this genre include 'The Hunger Games' by Suzanne Collins and 'The Fault in Our Stars' by John Green.
